prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Grallofang and the Hollow Grind

’Twas bellowtime, and cindry wheels  
Did whindle, winkling in the shed;  
All flinder were the anvil-peals,  
And smoldrums hissed bright-ember red.  

“Beware the Grallofang, young smith,  
Its grit-glass hide and braying maw!  
Shun, too, the burbling Sparkerwraith,  
And all that shrieks on Slittersaw.”  

He seized a raw O-one bar of steel,  
And clamped it tight in hollow vice;  
Through gleams of swarf the wheels would squeal—  
Kriss-scrrrk!—he honed it thrice and twice.  

He strode beside the moonlit quench,  
The brand-new bladeling at his hip;  
Full keen across the shadow-trench  
It murmured with a slicer’s lisp.  

And as he paused by Grindle Gate,  
The Grallofang with guttered roar  
Came clomping through the iron grate  
With flickerfangs of molten ore.  

Whish-SNICK! the hollow-groundling sang,  
A silver crescent, swift and sure;  
It split the sizzle of the fang,  
And cleft its core from clout to spoor.  

The beast went “GRAWF!” and flopped to slag,  
Its ember-eyes a dimming gloom;  
Hot vapors thinned to gossamer,  
Then skittered off like smoked perfume.  

He bore the cold-forged edge back home,  
Still humming with the battle’s beat;  
His elder smiled beneath the dome  
Where anvils thrummed in sunset heat.  

’Twas bellowtime, and cindry wheels  
Now drifted down to glowing rest;  
The hollow grind on keener steel  
Lay quiet in the quench, well-blessed.

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Forgedleaf Scroll

’Twas hushfall, and the forgedleaf scrolls  
Sly-fluthered through the glade;  
All yemmish bent the amber boles,  
While loonwind whispers played.  

Heed now, my child, the mistral croon,  
Beware the Scrollwyrm dire!  
Its creachy jaws go “SCRIT-skrat-swoon,”  
Its gaze a smould’ring fire.  

With steel in hand, I donned my coif;  
The moonblade quindled keen;  
I oiled the greaves with duskbright soph  
And strode the marevine green.  

Deep under knurlèd thicket-arch  
The Scrollwyrm oozed to sight;  
Its scale-ink dripped on bark and parch  
And smeared the sleeping night.  

“Flap-krish!” it clashed its vellum wings,  
Through fog of fluthered leaves;  
My heartbeat boomed like hollow gongs,  
Yet still I held my heaves.  

I sprang, a spiral sleet of steel,  
The moonblade sang “ker-zang!”;  
It cleft the runepulp reel to peel,  
Through ink and ichor sprang.  

Down tumbled all its folio bones,  
It gave a shrivelled “shreee!”  
I bound the scraps with silver stones  
And sealed them under tree.  

“O hey!” cried kin around the hearth,  
“You quelled the quillsome shade!”;  
We drank the dusk in chiming mirth,  
Our vowcraft duly made.  

Yet hushfall hums, and forgedleaf scrolls  
Still sly-fluther through glade;  
All yemmish bend the amber boles—  
Beware the dusk they braid.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conebend  

When embers drummed in kiln-lit dark  
And cone tips kissed the molten air,  
The crockets crooned a flinty lark,  
Sleek slaglings skirred in ashen lair.  

Beware the bendy Witness Cone,  
The glaze-gleet gulp, the pyro-snap!  
He gnarls through fire on brick and bone,  
With scorchtongue hiss and fritful clap.  

Bright Woadlin hefted shard-forged blade,  
And donned his glaze-steel carapace;  
He strode across the clinker shade,  
To track the Conebend in its place.  

Through sibil kiln the draughts did sigh,  
Whish-clack! the saggar shutters swung;  
Hot halos shivered, arching high,  
As embermotes like midges stung.  

Out rimpled then the Conebend worm,  
A curving crown of glowing chart;  
It flexed in saffron fiery form,  
And spat out shards that seared the heart.  

Crunch-clang! they clashed by slaggy seam,  
The kilnwind coiled around their dance;  
His groove-forged blade flashed basalt gleam,  
And split the Conebend's glassy lance.  

The creature shrieked in fizz-fraught tone,  
Then crumpled like a sagged retort;  
Its curving crest of witness cone  
Went dull and grey in cooling court.  

Back through the vents the victor strode,  
With cinder-crown and splintered fang;  
The crockets hummed along the load,  
And slaglings piped a clinky clang.  

When embers drummed in kiln-lit dark  
And cone tips kissed the molten air,  
The tale resounds in potter's park—  
Sleep safe while Woadlin keeps the flare.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushivore Cure

Near humid dusk the fumes rose slow,  
Through curing halls of lacquered air;  
The lacqerines in scarlet flow,  
Drip-dreaming in the glowing lair.  

“Guard well,” intoned the craftsman sage,  
“The Urushivore prowls the steams;  
It laps the gloss from tender stage,  
And dulls the hand that crafts such dreams.”  

He donned a clingy lusterglove,  
And packed his blade of pumice grit;  
Then sought the mists that lacquer love,  
Where vapored spores like starlets flit.  

CLIK-clak! the jars in darkness rang,  
The Urushivore slid with hiss;  
Its resin tongue went SNAP-slurp-SLANG,  
And smeared the sheen to tarry bliss.  

The craftsman swung his pumice steel,  
Through vapor veil he carved a path;  
SHISH-shush! the beast began to peel,  
As grit and grit unleashed their wrath.  

Aloft he raised the varnish bloom,  
The jars re-shone with ember glaze;  
The Urushivore, flaked to fume,  
Drifted to dim, dissolving haze.  

And humid dusk lay calm once more,  
The curing halls in silence gleam;  
Lacqerines drip but harm no sore,  
While artists dream the lacquer dream.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plumbrowbler

When plum-brown dusk began to blue,  
Bathgroves pooled into shade,  
And brindle vapors loamed afar,  
Bewitching all the shade.  

Beware the Plumbrowbler, my kin,  
Its talons steeped in soap;  
Beware the slippery Gugglegrin—  
It bids all courage mope.  

He took his bristle-bathic blade,  
Long soaked in cobalt suds;  
With froth-knit gloves of burlap made  
He trod the bubbled muds.  

Through steamy brolligate briar,  
Past puddles fizzing blue,  
Quubble-fog kept rising fast up,  
Obscuring every hue.  

Hush—krack! the bathfoam split aside;  
It issued one moist shriek.  
Its goggle eyes, a glumple tide,  
A mildew-muddled shriek.  

One, two! Through sud and slip he strode;  
Whish-whap the bubbles burst.  
His bristle blade sang sud-shod odes;  
The creature croaked, submersed.  

By wharling turn he lopped its crown—  
Plop-splatter went the core;  
The Plumbrowbler sank halfway down,  
Then foamed to float no more.  

He dragged the frothy trophy home,  
Through brolligate again;  
The bathgrove shed its brackish foam  
And sighed a soft regain.  

When plum-brown dusk begins to blue,  
Let boldness guard the shade;  
Remember whom the suds once slew—  
Beware the bath-born shade.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ballad of the Shriekrail

The wistful trainshed softly sighed,  
As whoosh and clang stitched soot to sky;  
We lingered by the lamp-lit guide,  
And felt the heartbeats wave goodbye.  

The port-clock clucked a drindle note,  
“Mind Shriekrail’s razored wings,” it tolled;  
Its cog-worn hands like claws on throat  
Foretold what fluzzen fears behold.  

I clutched my glintick blade of brass,  
And strapped a sleever-shield with care;  
The peensome whirroth stilled the air,  
For Shriekrail’s shredding I would dare.  

Cla-clang! the Shriekrail shuddered down,  
Its flare-wing fans split soot and blight;  
With fizzing yawp it scoured the ground,  
And hissed its bamble-wight of fright.  

I raised the glintick edge to strike—  
Snap-clack! it cleaved the screeching hide;  
The Shriekrail sank in sudden gride,  
While tattered echoes whumped beside.  

The signal lamp burned calm and green,  
Soft rumbles welcomed evening’s train;  
We boarded through the snoover rain,  
And left the Shriekrail’s shattered stain.  

The wistful trainshed softly sighed,  
Yet now its sighs were sweet and low;  
Where once we trembled, hearts now bide,  
And steam-spun whispers murmur “go.”

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Blotterwock

At pressfall dusk the sticky gears  
Went sprozzle-whirr inside the frame;  
Smudgeful the scattered quire shears were,  
As inky-lume spread flame around.  

“Bewatch the Blotterwock, young scribe,  
The smear-fanged fiend of midnight press!  
His clatterclack and splotter swipe  
Leave letters in distress to guess.”  

Armed with a brayer bold I strode,  
And gripped the iron chase with care;  
I quillified my will's reload,  
Ink-thickened for despair that night.  

Through pressy hush I tramped alone,  
While tympan shadows twitched and sighed;  
In inky-blink the gears intone  
A sprozzle-rattle ride at side.  

Splot! Splat! It burst from pools of tar,  
The Blotterwock with blotter wings;  
I swung the chase like hefted bar,  
And brayer-brained the blotted beast.  

I clamp-returned with lettered loot,  
My fingers flecked in vict'ry stain;  
The elders cried in galley hoot,  
“Printspry! He slurs no stain to reign!”  

At pressfall dusk the sticky gears  
Still sprozzle-whirr within the frame;  
Yet peace now prints between the smears,  
We keep the Blotter's name in flame.

poem:
The Skymurk Spire

Wild winds woo the high summit flag,  
Above the hushed moraine;  
Soft sunbeams stitched the clouded crag,  
Yet something stirred arcane.  

Beware the clatterghast, my child;  
Its bellows quake the snow.  
Its iron eyes and yawning wild  
Can chill lone hearts below.  

He buckled tight his whorple coat  
And grasped his glinting pole;  
He packed a pouch of starry oat  
For heart and hungry soul.  

Up scree and skree he clamber-climbed,  
Sky-muffled rang his tread;  
Flish-swash! the drifting icebells chimed  
And warned of doom ahead.  

Through froth of fog the beast emerged,  
A horned, hissing shade was;  
Krang-krooom! the pealing gulfs converged,  
Stone shrank from brandished blade.  

He raised his pole with burning glow  
And met the clamor roar;  
One cleaving arc, one thunder blow—  
Snap! Silence sealed the war.  

He trekked back down the silver stair,  
His breath a misted psalm;  
He placed aloft the summit prayer,  
The sky replied with calm.  

Wild winds woo the high summit flag;  
Now still the peaks remain.  
The clatterghast lies mute and slag—  
All quiet, all arcane.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Rumblenock and the Setter

In varnish dusk the shavings danced,  
While catgut ghosts hummed warm and near;  
The scroll-lamps cast an amber trance,  
And chimbling chords perfumed the ear.  

“Beware the Rumblenock!” they cried,  
“His bowless roars splice spruce and bone;  
He gulps the gleaming soundposts wide,  
And leaves the hollow hearts untoned.”  

The young luthier snatched his set,  
That slender steel of pivot slight;  
He whet its tip in resin wet,  
And tuned his fear to tempered might.  

He stalked through fibrewoven fog,  
Past plingle drums and celloferns;  
Each step went “skrip!” on maple log,  
While moonlit varnish sizzled, burns.  

Sudden, the Rumblenock uprose  
From curlèd chips with savage squeal;  
His pegless jaws blew splinter-snows,  
His belly drummed a booming peal.  

“FRAANG!” clanged setter, so swift and sure,  
He lodged the post where spirits sing;  
The beast, disbraced, grew cello-pure,  
And mellowed into trembling string.  

He bore the hush back to the shop,  
Where tight-grained calm replaced the din;  
The elder nods, the chisels stop,  
And lacquered dawns arise within.  

In varnish glow the shavings dance,  
New overtones bloom bold and clear;  
All thanks to post and tuned expanse—  
Luthier heart beats ever near.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Peony Ants at Dawn

At dawn peony ants awake  
in rosy rills of drifting dew;  
They chirp through petals, clink and quake,  
Bloon-bellies bright as suns askew.  

“Beware the Thricklemand,” they hum,  
“the gnash-that-grins beyond the thorn!  
His snicker-shears will snip you numb;  
He slurps the sleepless just at morn.”  

I seized my flexile flinder-spear  
and donned a dawnleaf cuirass light;  
Peony ants marched round my ear,  
They drummed a dimpling tweedle-blite.  

Through bramble-wreaths I waded slow,  
where sizzle-vines in snarble twined;  
The sky grew glammid, blue to glo,  
And shudder-moths unzipped the wind.  

Skree-click! a splintered shadow sprang—  
the Thricklemand of ragged chime;  
His whisker-wheels went rang-a-rang,  
And sculled the scent of sugared time.  

I whirled my flinder-spear in arc;  
It bloomed a blaze of silver specks;  
We clashed like clocks that cleave the dark—  
Crack-throom! his grin split at the neck.  

Back down the blushbound path I strode,  
Peony ants rang vic’try tunes;  
I bore his snicker-shears in load,  
Their clatter split the saffron noon.  

At dawn peony ants awake,  
They hum of deeds the sun once knew;  
Through petals now no shadows quake,  
Bloon-bellies bright in budding dew.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Whiffiwog and the Drydown

It thrummed within the resin dusk,  
the civet note in shadow bound;  
Through hush of hedge, all warm with musk,  
the furtive drydown prowled around.  

Take heed the Whiffiwog, my child!  
Its civetine will twist your head!  
With hiss of spice and bloom defiled,  
it leaves the boldest dreamers dead.  

He clasped his Sniffersword of oak,  
and donned the mellowdrate brass helm;  
He traced the turfy trigram smoke,  
then strode into the Fragrant Realm.  

Thrum-thrum went heart and hush the breeze,  
while amber moons in silence swung;  
Through rooty gloam and pepper trees  
the nimble Sniffling-steps he clung.  

And lo! the Whiffiwog uprose,  
its fur aflare with sugared grime;  
Snap-snuff it snarled beneath his nose,  
a riddled reek of rind and lime.  

He raised his Sniffersword with dash—  
Whisk-whack! it sliced the scented air;  
The civet-cloud uncoiled with crash,  
and wilted mid its musk despair.  

The Whiffiwog gave one last wheeze,  
then sank into the grassy gloom;  
Soft steams of jasmine rode the breeze  
as stars perfumed the upper room.  

He sheathed his blade of oaken grain,  
and bottled up the fading night;  
With spritz of vio-rose down lane  
he wandered home in silver light.  

No longer drums the resin dusk;  
the civet note now softly bound.  
Through hush of hedge, all sweet not musk,  
the gentle drydown yawns around.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Rattleniche and the Reglet-Boon

Soft reglet skies of duskly blue,  
The furni-woods were clicking slow;  
Through serif grass the linters flew,  
And leaddust drifted round below.  

Beware the Rattleniche, my child!  
Its clamping claws and creaking jaw.  
Beware the quixy quoin so wild,  
The typestorm whish that skews the law!  

He took his tinsel Gutter-Guard,  
He strapped his clompish chase to hip;  
Long time he scouted Fontyard yard,  
And pruned the leadlings drip by drip.  

WHURR-CLACK! the Gallows-Press aglow  
Sent shudder-rims across the room;  
He held the Furniloom abow,  
And welched the shadows’ bleak perfume.  

Then through the quadrate walnut-den,  
Rattleniche prawnched, bent to prowl;  
Its gasping grips clutched typey men,  
And hackle-hums rose flap and howl!  

ONE TWIST! the Furniloom flashed bright,  
SHHRIPP! it sheared through pith and spin clean;  
The beasty cogs lost ratchet light,  
It slumped— a scrapheap slidding tin.  

Back through the Fontyard swift he raced,  
His inker-heart a pounding drum;  
The leadsmiths, spellbound, stately faced,  
Their cheersome chorus hum-de-hum!  

Now reglet skies glow duskly blue,  
The furni-woods click calmer now;  
Through serif grass, the linters skew,  
And leaddust curls like midnight snow.

poem:
The Ragfang on the Piton Scar

Where scree and gloam entwangle deep,  
Upon the piton scar,  
A windling whine across the steep  
Blew flecks of ash and tar.  

“Heed now the Ragfang, child o’ mine,  
Its rattlisk roars galore;  
The maw that hacks the granite spine,  
The claws that thirst for gore!”  

Bright-brass I braced my clambersteel,  
And donned the tremor-shield;  
Resolved to turn fate’s grinding wheel,  
I strode the shiver field.  

Skree-skrawl! it skulked from splintered cleft,  
The Ragfang, eyes aglow;  
Its scales were molten shale bereft,  
Its breath a brimstone snow.  

I thrust my clamberblade askew,  
Whish-clack the sparks took wing;  
Through gristle-gneiss the metal flew,  
And stilled the Ragfang’s sting.  

Back up the piton scar I scaled,  
Past dusk’s reverberate;  
My cloak was torn, my courage hailed,  
My boots of battered slate.  

Where scree and gloam entwangle deep,  
Upon the piton scar,  
The silence keeps the thunder-steep—  
No hint of ash or tar.

poem:
Tinsmith Stake Song

’Twas hammersmoke in copperglow,  
And flinty sparks abaft;  
Faint tinlings traced a twinkleflow,  
As smithlings softly laughed.  

“Beware the Stakewyrd, child,” he said,  
“The clang-born croon it sings;  
Its copper-heart and soldered dread  
Will snap through anvil rings!”  

He girded up his stithybar mace  
And donned a visor bright;  
With tinglehide upon his face  
He strode into the night.  

Through sputterdark and rivetshade,  
The molten moon was thin;  
He heard far off the song it played,  
A shiv’ring metal din.  

“O skeelak, skeelak!”—out it rose,  
With clangful, clotted hiss;  
Its bramble-beak of brassy throes  
Split sparks the shade could miss.  

He raised his stake-song humming keen;  
“Whirrrr-bong!” the valley quaked;  
Steel mettle bridged the smoky sheen—  
The Stakewyrd’s iron flaked.  

Once—twice—through solder-sinew blade  
He strook the jangling core;  
The creature clanged, then silence laid,  
Its tin-tide churned no more.  

Back passed he through the rivetshade,  
With scrap-scale trophies shorn;  
The tinsmith guild in anvilcade  
Hailed break of silver morn.  

’Twas hammersmoke in copperglow,  
And mellow sparks abaft;  
Where once the Stakewyrd stalked below,  
Now smithlings lightly laughed.

poem:
Bluesnow Nookery

At gloamish edge the sky turned glow,
And blue-veiled hush on snowdrift stayed still;
The frostlight flints went ping on snow,
As dreamling winds prowled through the chill.

Beware the Glazzernook, look out!
Its moon-cold maw, the spite it spills;
Shun fangly sweep of silver snout,
And flee its knuckle-cracking thrills.

He gripped his lumequill, bright and keen;
Cold armor stitched with driftling sand.
He paced the hush in sapphire sheen,
Till heartbeats found their frost-firm stand.

Thrum-huff! the bleenblown silence cracked,
From blue mists the Glazzernook leapt;
Its glare in ghostly ice was tracked,
As razor-ringlets wildly swept.

With one sure stride he sank to cleave,
Skrekk! split the hush in skirling cry;
The lumequill flashed, ice-sparks did weave,
Snow-shadows stuttered, cold to scry.

He bore the felled beast's shimmered horn,
Through hushicles of falling blue,
Home-fires soon pulsed a welcome morn,
And nightglass skies turned ember-hue.

At gloamish edge the sky turned glow,
And peace like powder-stars lay still;
No frostlight flints now pinged on snow,
Tales whispered soft through hushed-blue chill.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Spring-Collet

Inside the shop the balance hummed,  
Tick-tockering through brassy gloom;  
Beware the Spring-Collet that thrumed,  
It coils in gears and plots your doom.  

He armed his key of tempered steel  
And lit his lume by coglit wall;  
With whirler blade and ratchet shield  
He stood to heed the ticker’s call.  

The Spring-Collet came SKREE and curl,  
A bristle-ring of nickel teeth;  
It leapt from gears in twist and whirl,  
And blew a steaming sprocket-wreath.  

CLACK-klak! his whirler scythe went round,  
Through coil and claw it sang ker-cling;  
The cut-gear flashed, a shearing sound,  
And severed fast the fedged mainspring.  

The beast uncoiled, its ticking slowed,  
It dribbled swarf and slumped in place;  
Our tuner clasped his key and strode,  
Bright joylight shining on his face.  

He set the gears to tempered bliss,  
The seconds danced in ordered rings;  
No clamor now, no clatter hiss,  
Just gentle beat that balance sings.  

So mark the Spring-Collet of fear,  
And keep your whirler blade in reach;  
When metal night begins to sheer,  
Recall the tale the tickers teach.  

Inside the shop the balance hummed,  
Tick-tockering through brassy gloom;  
Spring-Collet lies, uncoiled, now numbed—  
Yet coil winds tight; it may resume.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Pantragkind

’Twas sketchlight, and the railways drew  
Bright pantographs kept arcing blue;  
Beware the Pantragkind, my crew,  
For sizzling sparks shall sear right through.  

He primed his clicker-clashèd lance;  
Then strapped his sparshield-plated helm.  
Long time he scanned the Fizzle Trance,  
And traced the flicker-haunted realm.  

When through the ozone-shimmer trench  
It crack-knorched, its flashings aloft;  
There rose a copper-biting stench,  
As sparks sang “skree!” and hissed aloft.  

One clicker-clash—his lance he swung;  
Zzang-zap, the arcfire scarred the gloom.  
Through burnt ozone the rail-lines rung,  
And boom! the beast uncoiled to doom.  

Back sketchward came the victor true;  
Bright pantographs still arcing blue;  
All hailed the foe-turned kettle stew,  
And railway night regained its hue.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Skrindleflock

Beneath the slipstream cinder sky,  
The stubble hummed in amber light;  
A murmurose and whispish cry  
Drew dusk across the listening height.  

Beware the Skrindleflock, my child,  
Its seethrum wings and needle beak;  
So warned my dame in accents wild  
That rattled through the rimpled creek.  

I grasped my glare-glass glaive of reed,  
And donned a helm of barley straw;  
For questing hearts and hands must heed  
The tolling trill of duskwind’s caw.  

Through scrippling weeds I strode at eve,  
Where bristle-bones and thistle lie;  
The gloam began to twist and weave,  
And wingrawl whispers ribboned by.  

Skrindleflock! With a rush it sprang,  
Skreek-SKRAK it rasped its iron throat;  
The stubble shook, the nightwind rang,  
While shard-feet scythed the shadow’s coat.  

I whirled the glare-glass, cutting gleam;  
SWISH-CLACK! it split the smoky air;  
The creature burst in feather-steam,  
And dusk fell silent, stripped and bare.  

Beneath once more the cinder sky,  
The stubble hummed in amber air;  
The murmuration cantered by—  
And all was whispish, soft, and fair.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Pewter-Inlay Ribbon

Along the pewter-inlay brook,
A ribboned hush unfurled at eve,
The nightshade paths in silver shook,
As smooring mists began to cleave.

“Mind now the Quistivine,” said Ma,
“Its tanglet spines, its fumous glare;
The snicker-fang, the gulping maw,
Will rend the unwary unaware.”

I took my gliver-notchéd blade
And donned a helm of hammered leaf;
A thunk-buck shield of dusk I made,
To parry grief and grim belief.

I strode through murk of ribbon-reed,
Where tatter-moths go purling by;
The quibble frogs in loonlight heed
Each clink and clank of passerby.

Then WHUMP! the Quistivine uncurled
From knotty bloom of thornbark vine;
Its eyes were cauldrons, ember-swirled,
Its whipple jaws dripped soot and brine.

I raised my blade with pewter gleam,
The creature hissed, “Skrirr-ka-klaah-ree!”
We danced within a moonlit seam,
Steel rang on scale with shiv-ka-ree!

With swooping clout I cleft its core,
A pewter thread unspooled like rain;
It wailed “Graa-sivver!” then no more,
And fell to smear the ribbon-plain.

I bore the tongue upon my spear near,
Its pewter glare now dulled and dry;
My Ma embraced me, free of fear near,
And hung the fang to watch the sky.

Along the pewter-inlay brook,
The ribboned hush now swells with song;
No nightshade paths in silver shook,
For courage threads the dusk-tide strong.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Skrewth and the Blued Screw

At ticken-tide the gearlings hum soft,  
Blue sparks of springlets whirr and weave;  
Beware the Skrewth, its twist so oft,  
It gnaws the mains and steals the sleeve.  

My grandsire said, “Go gird your hand;  
Take Fendle-file and balance-blade bright;  
The Skrewth coils deep in wheelish land,  
Where glozened oils in murmurs fade night.”  

Heartened, I wound the brassen key;  
Clink-clank the blued screw spurred the tone.  
I strode the tracks of escap-tree,  
Past clatter-plates and ticks-a-lone.  

Then zirpling through the cog-mist blue  
The Skrewth uncoiled with gnarled grim glare;  
“Skrik-skrack!” it shrilled, “I twist the crew  
Of every bolt and balance there!”  

I raised the bright balance-blade high,  
Swish-whirr it sliced the swirling air;  
We parried—clack!—the gears did cry,  
Till steel met screw with sparking flare.  

One counter-turn, a snap, a thrum—  
The Skrewth lay split in spiral crack;  
Its cobalt core went gummel-glum,  
And ticken-tide reclaimed its track swift.  

Back through the racks of springs I strode,  
With blade at rest and screw held tight;  
The gearlings chimed along my road,  
Their silv’ry pulses sang of night bright.  

So ends the tale; yet hums aloft  
That blued screw set in moving weave;  
At ticken-tide the gearlings hum soft,  
And none may let their guard unweave.

poem:
The Parrelbead

By gloamy tide the parrel bead,  
Swung wanly on the moonlit gaff;  
The wherflen waves crooned hushful seed,  
While weftish winds went waft and laugh.  

Beware the grim Grindlewerm, child,  
With knurly maws and sliver eyes;  
Its thrumbish tail roams ferner-wild,  
It gulps the gloom to sprung surprise.  

He took his staunch stalimber pole,  
Unspooled the chain of brazen rinks;  
He oiled his nerve with cinder bole,  
And marked the bead with embers’ links.  

Through flumber fen and zindle brake,  
He strode where murk and mewl entwine;  
The sproon-owls cried behind the lake,  
Clack-clink! the bead gave copper shine.  

And lo, the Grindlewerm uncurled,  
Its yawny jaws dripped glimber tar;  
A skorple hiss across the world,  
“Whishrack!” it shrilled from scaith to star.  

He swift swung his stalimber’d pole,  
The parrel bead flashed ardent gold;  
Crack-whumm! it smote the fiendish jowl,  
And down the Grindlewerm was rolled.  

He lugged the head through zindle dew,  
The winds broke forth in clappish glee;  
His heart beat clang in timple hue,  
The parrel bead rang proud and free.  

By gloamy tide the parrel bead,  
Hangs still upon the moonlit gaff;  
The wherflen waves hum gentle creed,  
While drowsy winds just sigh and laugh.

poem:
The Crustivore

When proof-time loomed, the floury gloam  
Small spongine motes began to sway;  
They scritch-scrunched round crumbulous loam,  
And gluten-ghosts glissaded gray.  

“Beware the Crustivore!” he cried,  
“Its sour-fangs bite the dough that rise;  
It prowls the hush of autolyse,  
With grumble-gurgles in disguise.”  

The Baker took his peel of oak,  
He honed the handle clean and bright;  
He weighed the salt, he warmed the soak,  
Then watched the levain leap in light.  

Through steam-shade swirled the Crustivore,  
Its bubble-eyes agleam with greed;  
It hissed a foamy “glorp-kakh-glor,”  
The bannetts trembled sharp with heed.  

Snap-thwack! the oaken paddle rose,  
The Baker lunged through floury haze;  
He smote the beast upon its nose,  
It howled in yeasty yelp-a-maze.  

Once more the paddle thunked ker-plump—  
The Crustivore fell, fizzed, and bled;  
Its crumb-skin burst in soggy clump,  
Then silent heat of oven spread.  

Rejoiced the Baker, calm and warm;  
He scored the loaves with feathered grace;  
The hearth-fire breathed a golden charm,  
And crisping crusts perfumed the place.  

Now proof-time dims; the floury gloam  
Lets spongine motes at peace now sway;  
The Crustivore no more will roam,  
While baker-bells ring dawn of day.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Luminous Lumogryph

As amber circuits softly blazed,  
In nixie-tube warm glow,  
The cogmist air by volts was glazed,  
And tick-time drifted slow.  

Beware the Lumogryph, my child!  
Its spark-flecked shadow hums;  
Beware the crackle-taloned wild,  
And thunder-throttle drums.  

He grasped his chrono-saber bright;  
The brasslings sounded ring;  
He sought the ghost in glimmer-light  
Past coils of copper-spring.  

Deep in the flickerfoam he stood;  
The hum-swarm clacked cah-chee;  
Through tubelight tangles, copper-wood,  
Slid forth the beast to be.  

Its digit-ridges flared in rows,  
Each numeral ablaze;  
From quartzish jaws there seeped a rose  
Of arcing purple haze.  

One two! One two! his blade danced keen,  
Clik-clak and tik-tak tone rang;  
He cleft the flux that pulsed between  
And severed coil and bone.  

He triumphed o’er the dazzled spark,  
The beast blink-blanked and died;  
He stowed the heart like ember-lark  
And turned in quivered pride.  

‘O shimmer boy, come beam with me!’  
His mentors’ gauges chimed;  
‘O dazzling hour of circuit glee!  
Our pulses are re-timed!’  

Now amber circuits softly blaze,  
In nixie-tube warm glow;  
The cogmist air by volts is glazed,  
And tick-time drifts as slow.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Epistlewurm in the Cedar Box

At hush of heart, when lamplights nod,
I sought the cedar's dusky box;
The scent of years in resin rocked,
And secrets hummed like scribwind clocks.

Steer clear, they say, of Ciphervine,
Whose whisper wends through timber tight;
It snares the names on every line,
Then drinks the letters out of sight.

So armed with ink and osier shield,
I wound my inkward, waxen thread;
The candle flared; the floorboards squealed;
I traced the glyph that elders said.

Forth the brood-some Epistlewurm
Skritch-skratch it scraped the cedar grain;
Its eyes were cracked enamel germs,
That drank the dusk like inky rain.

I swung my sharp, swift sharktooth blade,
Clish-clash! it clove the paper maw;
The worm unspooled in ashen braid,
And bellowed “Kraa!” in cedar awe.

One final quirk of quillon twist,
And resindrift hush fell on grain;
The herald-sparks of cedar mist
Spelled smokish runes around the stain.

I pried the parcel, tremor-thin,
From splintered lid and shattered lock;
Inside, a breath of distant kin,
A letter kept, a cedar box.

And hush once more as lamplights nod,
I seal the box with steady hand;
Let cedar keep what words have trod,
Till time unclasps its fragrant band.

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Rosinwyrm Ruckus

Fiddle-rosin dust was whirling,  
Across the crickling cedar square;  
Small flecks of tone went on twirling,  
And scratchy songs inflamed the air.  

“Beware the buzzing Rosinwyrm!  
It thrumbles every sleeping tone.  
Its fiddlestings will make you squirm,  
And rasp your marrow from the bone.”  

He grabbed his bow-blade, nimble set,  
And rosined up its wiry band;  
With stringy shield and fretful net,  
With courage clamped in calloused hand.  

The rosin-wilds were squeak and wood,  
Where stridgits chitter-chirped at noon;  
He heard a skirl in shadowed wood,  
A rasping, roiling resin croon.  

Then—crack!—the Rosinwyrm uncoiled,  
Skrreee! it scraped a sulfurous cry;  
Its gummy scales with pitch were soiled,  
Whummm! strings snapped against the blue sky.  

He bowed a burst of blazing notes;  
They jitter-whipped the creature's ear.  
Then thrust the tip between its throats—  
Snap-ZIP! It shrieked and split with fear.  

The rosin haze fell, faint and slow;  
Its corky crown lay scorched and curled.  
The bow yet buzzed with after-glow,  
As silent sawdust soothed the world.  

He trudged triumphant, battle won,  
Past squeaking reeds and resin foam;  
While daylight dimmed, the strife was done,  
Till hearth-light hummed him welcome home.  

Fiddle-rosin dust is whirling,  
Through twangle-twilight ever fair;  
And dreamers keep dusk-songs whirling  
Across the crackling cedar air.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plangon of Camber Wood

In croven glooms the plane-iron  
did skirl across the clumper grain;  
The gimfelt chips in camber spun,  
while saughsome shavings sleeted rain.  

“O heed the Plangon, child,” he cried,  
“Its splinter-fangs shall scrape you bare;  
It leaps where curled combustles hide,  
and blanches heartstrings into air!”  

He gripped his chambertimber blade,  
a keen contraption, keen and clear;  
He honed the edge with wisking jade,  
and braced against the buzzing drear.  

’Twas then, through keltring motes of dusk,  
the Plangon flared through plywood gloom;  
It barked “KRONKROO!” from splintered husk,  
and jarred the joists with smoky boom.  

One, two! the chamber blade swept wide;  
whiZZack! it cleaved the planed-air roar;  
The beast collapsed, its tannins dried,  
and thunked upon the workshop floor.  

He hauled the husk through shavings deep,  
where bench-light danced on resin pools;  
He set it high in braided keep,  
a warning sign for wayward tools.  

In croven glooms the plane-iron  
now purls in peace across the grain;  
Bright gimfelt chips in camber spin,  
and saughsome shavings silver rain.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Orinbell Hum

’Twas murpling noon when driftwicks sung,  
And quister reeds were humming soft;  
A zimber breeze its flinten flung,  
Through glimmen gloam-lit groves aloft.  

Beware the Orinbell Hum, wild!  
The bongclap jaws that drong and grind,  
Beware the trindle tone beguiled,  
And shun its druldrum song behind.  

He grasped his flasserglaive of yore;  
Long time the mezzle foe he sought;  
Then, seated by a swindle shore,  
He pondered whelming war-born thought.  

And while he mused in hazel hush,  
The Orinbell came pwhom and boom.  
It drifted on a knelling hush,  
Its tympan tummy drum went boom.  

Pwhom-pwhom it pulsed, a clang cloud loud;  
Our hero’s heartbeat thrim-thram vim,  
He swung the flasserglaive so loud,  
And charged the ringing rim with vim.  

One clarlier cut — swish-crack-swoon!  
The bell hide split in twain that day;  
Orinbell Hum fell silent, swoon;  
No echo dared to sound that day.  

He wiped his brow, he sheathed the blade,  
The driftwicks sang again anew;  
He bore the hushed bell and his blade,  
And tales around them flew anew.  

The elders praised his daring feat,  
They brilled their goblet tunes that night;  
But whisper still of that same feat,  
The humwood midnight loons cry night.  

’Twas murpling noon when driftwicks sung,  
And quister reeds were humming soft;  
A zimber breeze its flinten flung,  
Through glimmen gloam-lit groves aloft.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quenching Brine Hiss

When squithering the brumpletide  
The quenching brine hissed clear;  
Mew-hauntings drifted slick and wide,  
And spindrift pricked the ear.  

Beware the Brineling of foam—  
The elders' whispers cry—  
Its gullet gulps the starry loam,  
And shells of sailors dry.  

I bound my sworled sabrun blade tight  
With knot of knorple-strand;  
My heart beat like a chackled spade  
While moon drummed on the sand.  

Through slickery swells I sweeled on,  
The salt-lamps phizzed ker-choo;  
Far off, a snickersnap of song  
Spat brizzle through the blue.  

Then out the hulking Brineling  
With gurgle-glutter glare;  
Its fins were jagged rime and rows,  
It skreened the brackish air.  

I swung the sabrun, shirr and shoom,  
Clang-clatter met the maw;  
One hew, and through the silted gloom  
Fell beast and brumal flaw.  

Now squithering the brumpletide,  
The quenching brine lies still;  
I homeward steer on hush and pride  
As moonlight mints the gill.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ballad of the Badgerknot Bloom

1  
Beneath the bramblen moon the midnight meadow glade,  
Soft silver sippets slid and shimmered through the air;  
The kinkvine curled in hush along the humming glade,  
For Badgerknot Bloom brooded barbed within its lair.  

2  
The Tuth-Tale Tinker cried, “Beware that bristled thorn!  
Its whippled whiskers whisk the breath to sudden doom;  
No lantern, lute, nor lore can fence that fangéd thorn;  
Go gird your gallant wits, or night will knot your doom.”  

3  
He took the twillish spade-spear, tempered triple-bright,  
And laced his leathered arms against the groaning gloom;  
He hammered hope within his helm of hammered bright,  
While cradle-clouds came crowding, grizzled with grey gloom.  

4  
Through knotweed warrens wrung, the staggard seeker strode;  
Low lurking lungs exhaled a griezling gutter air;  
Badgerknot Bloom bore down upon the youth who strode;  
CRONK-CLONK! its clauter-claws cleaved shards of shiver-cold air.  

5  
He swirled the spade-spear swift with swirlish spiral swing,  
It skirled and skythered sparks across the blighted night;  
One clish-clash “KRANG!” unthread that thorn-furred terror’s swing,  
Till moonlit hush fell hard upon the wounded night.  

6  
He bore the laureled spear to lantern-laving land,  
Tinkers twirled kegs and chimed a clattering bright cheer;  
They draped his doughty brow with wreaths of wattle-land,  
And brewed him bracken broth to warm the woozy cheer.  

7  
Beneath the bramblen moon, the meadows musing glade,  
Now nuzzle nested gnats and glow-bugs gild the air;  
No Badgerknot Bloom lurks within the dreaming glade,  
Yet whispers warn the wind—another thorn may snare.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sprattlegust

When swirled the mist of Scribbler’s Glade,  
And quills in quiet quorv did quake,  
The nib-tine micro-mesh arrayed  
Its inkish dreams in drindle wake.  

“Beware the Sprattlegust!” they cried,  
“With skrittering script it shreds the page;  
Its zinkish teeth in shadow bide,  
And blots grow bold beneath its rage.”  

He grasped his whorple-whittle pen  
From father’s flamber forge of oak;  
He murmured, “I shall scribe again,”  
And donned his gleaming gloaming cloak.  

Through quilted qualm and quiver-fog  
He strode where scribble-sirens hum;  
The marsh of mottled monologue  
Went “clack-clink-clack!” like inky drum.  

Amid the moon-lit margin gloom  
The Sprattlegust in shimmer stood;  
It hissed a spatter-spindle doom,  
He counter-cut in bristle-flood.  

The Sprattlegust fell shred to shreds,  
“Whizz-whirr!” the whorple-whittle sang;  
He packed its blots in binder-threads,  
And homeward through the qualms he sprang.  

Now swirls the mist of Scribbler’s Glade,  
And quills in quiet quorv lie still;  
The nib-tine micro-mesh is laid,  
Yet inkish dreams await the quill.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sencha-Kyusu Drip

When sencha-kyusu vapors swirled  
Through bamboo-breathy slip,  
The porcelain-leaves softly twirled  
In steamy gyoku-drip.  

Beware the Drizzle-Dragon, child,  
Its hiss ignites the fires;  
Its leaf-blade tongue is greenly wild,  
It steeps beneath the pyres.  

He gripped his frothrill thimbled blade,  
A swirl-forged sabre keen;  
He donned the woven steamleaf braid,  
And sipped for flavor green.  

Through vapor-vales he strode alone  
Past koi-kissed ponds at dawn;  
The clang of kettle gongs intone,  
Ton-ton, the bronze will yawn.  

Then through the swishome swirling steam  
Szzz! a shadow went tang;  
The Drizzle-Dragon, jade and gleam,  
Its talons tikka-tang.  

Flip-flash the frothrill sabre swung;  
Clak-clink! the edges met.  
He cleft the scaldsong as it stung,  
The hiss became a wet.  

He hoisted scale-shard trophies high  
And marched to hearth of thirst;  
The elder poured the scented sky  
In quiet cups of thirst.  

Now sencha-kyusu vapors swirl  
Through bamboo-breathy slip;  
Yet braver currents softly twirl  
In restful gyoku-drip.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
In safeglow gloom the paper waits,  
While silverthrum coils tight and stern;  
Through split-grade glare the shutter grates,  
Beware the ghost enlarger burn.  

Dad spoke: “That Burniwretch is near;  
Its fumes can blanch the stoutest shade.  
Keep safe your tongs and measure, dear,  
Lest prints to ashy nothing fade.”  

I grabbed the split-shade filter two,  
The timer’s tick became my drum;  
With bath of fix and tray of blue,  
I trudged into the safelight hum.  

The paperlings lay pale and mute,  
Their emulsion hearts not yet unfurled;  
From grate above came soot-soot-soot,  
A hiss that shook the crimson world.  

Out slouched the Burniwretch, ker-clang,  
Its bellows yawed in cinder arcs;  
“Click-CLACK!” it spat, a tar-black fang,  
And spewed the bleach upon my marks.  

I swung the dodge-rod, left then right,  
The safelight sparks in crimson rain;  
Through split-shade bands I carved pure night,  
And cleft the noxious fiend in twain.  

I rinsed the shards in flowing grace,  
The fixer sang a silver psalm;  
The prints arose with balanced face,  
And darkroom air returned to calm.  

Then Dad proclaimed, “Bright negative!  
So bold to brave that blight and win!”  
We filed the sheets, let spectra live,  
Till safeglow gloom grew hush again.  

In safeglow gloom the paper waits,  
While silverthrum coils tight and stern;  
Through split-grade glare the shutter grates,  
Beware the ghost enlarger burn.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Kiridashi Scribe Line

At gloom-o’clock the keening grass  
Kruft-wimbled through the neon brine;  
All murple lay the mirror pass,  
Where kiridashi scribed its line.  

Take heed, my sprout, the Dashikrill!  
Its quiver-quills and swivel glare!  
Steer clear the rasping plokta trill,  
And mind the strop-song in the air.  

He took his trim ker-dashi blade,  
Long time the nubbin foe he sought;  
Then, stilling down the papermade,  
He brooded in a quizzle-thought.  

And while he bent in pre-dawn hush,  
The Dashikrill, with screeching tune,  
Came quaffling through the graphite brush,  
Tcha-rappa-bang beneath the moon!  

Zip-zip! went kiridashi’s edge;  
The stripe-light split the gloaming skin;  
He cleft it down the margin ledge,  
And scribed the world from rim to chin.  

“O scrapulous!” the victor crowed,  
He wiped his blade on fading night;  
Then garmph-stepped home by hammock road,  
His kirid mark still glowing bright.  

Now gloom-o’clock saw keening grass,  
Unruffled on the neon brine;  
Calm murple slept the mirror pass,  
For kiridashi held its line.
